name: Surveillance Protocols in Marfan Syndrome
description: Lifelong aortic surveillance is mandatory in Marfan syndrome to detect progressive dilation, enable timely prophylactic surgery, and identify new aortic pathology. Surveillance includes regular imaging of the entire aorta with echocardiography, CT, or MRI. Frequency is determined by aortic size, rate of growth, and surgical history. Standardized measurement techniques are essential for accurate comparison over time.

statement.text: Lifelong aortic surveillance is mandatory in Marfan syndrome to detect progressive dilation, enable timely prophylactic surgery, and identify new aortic pathology, using echocardiography, CT, or MRI with frequency determined by aortic size and growth rate.
statement.formal: Marfan Surveillance: Stable (<4.0cm) → Annual Echo + Periodic CT/MRI | Dilating (4.0-4.5cm) → 6-month Echo | Approaching Threshold → 3-month Echo + Surgical Planning

explanation.intuition: Marfan syndrome is a progressive disease - the aorta doesn't stop growing. Regular imaging catches dangerous dilation before it becomes catastrophic, allowing planned surgery rather than emergency operation with much higher mortality.
explanation.key_insight: Surveillance must continue AFTER aortic root replacement because 30% of Marfan patients develop distal aortic disease. The genetic defect affects the entire aorta, not just the root.
explanation.technical_details: Echocardiography is first-line for root surveillance. Complete aortic imaging (CT or MRI, head to pelvis) should be done periodically. MRI is preferred for long-term surveillance to avoid cumulative radiation. Use consistent measurement techniques for valid serial comparisons.

measurements.sinuses_of_valsalva: Leading edge to leading edge, largest diameter

limitations: Limited visualization of arch and descending aorta
May underestimate in some body habitus
transthoracic_echocardiography.z_score: Use for pediatric patients and normalization to body surface area

ct_angiography.role: Complete aortic imaging - baseline and periodic surveillance

measurements.technique: Measure outer wall to outer wall
measurements.ecg_gating: Essential for accurate ascending aortic measurements

advantages: Visualizes entire aorta from root to bifurcation
limitations: Radiation exposure (concern for young, lifelong surveillance)
when_to_use: Baseline complete aortic imaging at diagnosis
Every 3-5 years for complete aortic assessment
If new symptoms or rapid growth

mri_mra.recommendation: Preferred over CT for routine complete aortic surveillance due to no radiation

baseline_at_diagnosis.complete_aortic_imaging: CT or MRI from root to iliac bifurcation

rapid_growth.action: Consider early surgery even if below 5.0 cm threshold

after_root_replacement.importance: Critical - distal aorta at ongoing risk
after_root_replacement.annual_imaging: CT or MRI of entire aorta annually
after_root_replacement.late_dilation_rate: Up to 30% develop distal aortic disease

after_arch_or_descending_repair.surveillance: Focus on remaining native aortic segments

reproducibility.same_modality: Use same modality for serial comparisons when possible

conversion.note: Echo measurements systematically smaller than CT/MRI due to leading-edge technique
conversion.adjustment: Add ~2mm to echo measurement for comparison with CT (per ACC/AHA guidelines)
conversion.reference: Hiratzka LF, et al. 2010 ACCF/AHA Guidelines

orthopedic.screening: As needed for scoliosis, pectus, or joint symptoms

red_flags_requiring_urgent_evaluation: Sudden chest, back, or abdominal pain
Rapid growth on imaging (>3mm in 6 months)
clinical_pearls: Annual echo is MINIMUM - more frequent if dilated or growing
Complete aortic imaging (CT/MRI) is required periodically, not just echo
30% develop distal aortic disease - surveillance after root surgery is LIFELONG
Use consistent measurement technique for valid serial comparisons
learning_objectives: Design an appropriate surveillance protocol for Marfan syndrome based on aortic size
Compare imaging modalities for aortic surveillance in Marfan syndrome
Explain the importance of continued surveillance after aortic root replacement
